data.name: Space Journey (1): If only i knew where to land..
data.description:
Space Journey (1): If only I knew where to land...

Prologue:

As you are reaching your target planet the alarm goes off, the trajectory of your spaceship seems to be off by a fraction of a degree. You start wondering on how to fix this bug for future missions but as you start working through the code you realize that the new trajectory is on a collision course with that planet. "What are the odds?" you think to yourself. ```Avoiding the collision``` doesn't seem to be an option but your engines would be strong enough to allow a survivable landing ```if you could land on a liquid``` such as water. Luckily water is the exact reason for which you find yourself in this mess:
Your research had proven the formation of water vapor clouds on this planet!
Sadly, you have no further data on the planet except for a ```height map``` of the surface that you had gathered during your study... As your time starts running short you come up with a ```brilliant idea```. Maybe you can calculate the most probable area for a water deposit on your landing range the same way it was done for rivers and lakes back in the day:
by calculating where the rain water would flow based on the height map! You can deviate your landing site by about 250m in every direction.
This gives you a possible landing area of 250 000 m^2 and with the height maps details being down to 2500m^2 you have ```100 possible landing areas``` to examine...
It's time to hurry up!

The Task:

You will be given a 2 dimensional int array ```int[10,10]``` representing the average height of your 100 possible landing sites. The task is to calculate the most suitable area for landing: The area where water is more likely to form something like a lake or a river based on the rains flow and to return its coordinates. For a matter of simplicity following rules apply:
1) The rain falls completely evenly on the area
2) Everything outside of the 10x10 area is NOT to be considered:
-Water cannot flow outside of the 10x10 area
-No Water will enter the 10x10 area from the outside
3) No 2 neighboring tiles will have the same height
4) Water can only flow horizontally and vertically and NOT diagonally
5) Water will flow completely to the neighboring tile with the lowest height
6) The given numbers will always result in only 1 correct answer
Example in a 3x3 environment:
Input as Height Map:
3 4 5
8 1 6
6 2 4
making a "Flow Map" out of the Height Map:
[(>: flow to the right) (<: flow to the left) (^: flow up) (v: flow down)(o: no flow) ]
__x0|x1|x2
y0) o v <
y1) > o <
y2) > ^ <
Assuming that 1 unit of water falls on every tile before applying the flow:
1 0 0
0 8 0
0 0 0
Area (1,1) is the most suitable for landing so i return the string (1,1): ```return "(1,1)"```
